content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this challenge.  The range for 'val' has been changed to be within an 'int' value for C++ and the likes.  From codybumba's feedback, the variable I was changed so that it compiles in all languages.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Numbers are too big to handle in C++ in Test Case 7 and Validation 8. Please keep it within "long long int" range.

The default code has compilation error due to duplicate variable name "i" in C++. Please fix that.

This is classic one. I liked the problem. But reading the input is bit challenging in programming languages like C++. There is no trivial way to split string by space in C++ for example like Python does.

What about considering number of person (n) as input and reading identification number sequentially instead of reading as string?

Note: This is worth considering before approval.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The idea is nice and simple, one of those easier tasks, which are nice to face in CoC. After a couple of fixes I approve.
Really simple and fun puzzle. I really liked the test case where you changed up just the last 4 digits

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple to understand and fun.

Nice idea, just a few details. 
* the input of the fifth test contains extra white space at the end
* the constraint is weird, you were probably referring to the length of the string (which should be described as such), while the future solvers will be much more interested in the contraint about the values
* check how to format the description - you used {n}, which doesn't work
* just a detail - referring to both input and output as [[S]] is slightly confusing
Maybe have the outputs be "yes"/"no" so Python isn't given an unfair advantage?

How about outputs be 1 or 0?
That way it will not be frustrating two increase code size just because of the output, right?

Thanks for pointing these out! 
I have modified the statement, let me know if further improvements are required.

Please check that the autogenerated stub works in all programming languages before accepting.  This code can't compile on 3 languages because the stub uses the variable "I" in a loop, which makes a conflict.  Also, the "long" keyword is incorrectly substituted into one language.

Please check that the autogenerated stub works in all programming languages before accepting.  This code can't compile on 3 languages because the stub uses the variable "I" in a loop, which makes a conflict.  Also, the "long" keyword is incorrectly substituted into one language.
Modified the statement, I think it can be managed now. Thanks for pointing out.

Restricted the numbers to be less than 10^19.

Thanks for mentioning, the default variable for loop in stub is i (I didn't knew that) changed it, works now.

Yes, that seems like a reasonable compromise. I see you've updated the puzzle, so thanks for that, but it feels like you have it the wrong way around. It's technically fine, but 1 usually indicates "yes", so it's odd that we should output 0 if the criterion is met. Mostly just a nitpick, though.

There are 2 reasons, for that:

Firstly, I want the programmers to not rush with the statement and to actually read the statement.

The other reason, is using bit-wise operators for verifying powers of 2, (x & (x-1)) is 0. So it can be used a hint, or can be used in the solution directly.
